sn35.95:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn35.95:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta went up to the Buddha … and asked him,
sn35.95:1.1.comm: Māluṅkyaputta was, according to Pali commentaries, the son of the lady Māluṅkyā of Kosala. Alternatively, Sanskrit dictionaries give māluka as the name of a people or a mixed caste, although I have not been able to trace any further details. His conversion is not recorded as he appears always as a monk. MN 63 and MN 64 depict him as somewhat of a fool, but it seems that he persisted, and late in life sought teachings in meditation and ultimately realized arahantship, of which we have two different accounts (here and AN 4.257). The latter contains an extensive set of verses attributed to him, which are repeated at Thag 16.5. A second set of his verses are at Thag 6.5.

sn35.95:1.2.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
sn35.95:1.2.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

sn35.95:2.1.pli: “Ettha dāni, mālukyaputta, kiṃ dahare bhikkhū vakkhāma.
sn35.95:2.1.eng: “Well now, Māluṅkyaputta, what are we to say to the young monks,

sn35.95:2.2.pli: Yatra hi nāma tvaṃ, bhikkhu, jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto saṅkhittena ovādaṃ yācasī”ti.
sn35.95:2.2.eng: when even an old man like you, elderly and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life, asks for brief advice?”

sn35.95:3.1.pli: “Kiñcāpāhaṃ, bhante, jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto.
sn35.95:3.1.eng: “Sir, even though I’m an old man, elderly and senior,

sn35.95:3.2.pli: Desetu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ, desetu sugato saṅkhittena dhammaṃ, appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājāneyyaṃ. Appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa dāyādo assan”ti.
sn35.95:3.2.eng: may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief! May the Holy one please teach me in brief! Hopefully I can understand the meaning of what the Buddha says. Hopefully I can be an heir of the Buddha’s teaching!”

sn35.95:4.2.pli: ye te cakkhuviññeyyā rūpā adiṭṭhā adiṭṭhapubbā, na ca passasi, na ca te hoti passeyyanti? Atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.95:4.2.eng: Do you have any desire or greed or fondness for sights known by the eye that are unseen, unseen before, and which you neither see nor think might be seen?”
sn35.95:4.2.comm: The commentary explains “unseen, unseen before” as not seen in this life or past lives. This is possible, although adiṭṭhapubba (and its parallels) are elsewhere used for the simple past in this life (eg. DN 16:2.17.3, SN 35.245:6.1; assutapubba at MN 12:50.6).

sn35.95:5.1.pli: “Ye te sotaviññeyyā saddā assutā assutapubbā, na ca suṇāsi, na ca te hoti suṇeyyanti? Atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.95:5.1.eng: “Do you have any desire or greed or affection for sounds known by the ear …

sn35.95:6.1.pli: “Ye te ghānaviññeyyā gandhā aghāyitā aghāyitapubbā, na ca ghāyasi, na ca te hoti ghāyeyyanti? Atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?

sn35.95:7.1.pli: “Ye te jivhāviññeyyā rasā asāyitā asāyitapubbā, na ca sāyasi, na ca te hoti sāyeyyanti? Atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?

sn35.95:8.1.pli: “Ye te kāyaviññeyyā phoṭṭhabbā asamphuṭṭhā asamphuṭṭhapubbā, na ca phusasi, na ca te hoti phuseyyanti? Atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?

sn35.95:9.1.pli: “Ye te manoviññeyyā dhammā aviññātā aviññātapubbā, na ca vijānāsi, na ca te hoti vijāneyyanti? Atthi te tattha chando vā rāgo vā pemaṃ vā”ti?
sn35.95:9.1.eng: ideas known by the mind that are unknown, unknown before, and which you neither know nor think might be known?”

sn35.95:10.1.pli: “Ettha ca te, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhasutamutaviññātabbesu dhammesu diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissati, sute sutamattaṃ bhavissati, mute mutamattaṃ bhavissati, viññāte viññātamattaṃ bhavissati.
sn35.95:10.1.eng: “In that case, when it comes to things that ought be seen, heard, thought, and known: in the seen will be merely the seen; in the heard will be merely the heard; in the thought will be merely the thought; in the known will be merely the known.
sn35.95:10.1.comm: For the “epistemic tetrad”, see MN 1:19.1. This teaching is famous from the brief instructions for Bāhiya at Ud 1.10:8.2 | This set of four overlaps but does not map neatly on to the six senses, which lack an equivalent for “thought”; this is the only place in the Suttas that connects them. Rather, they emphasize the means by which spiritual truths are known. The missing items smell, taste, and touch are not normally means of learning spiritual truths, unlike the “seen” (a holy person, a dream, etc.), the “heard” (the words of a teacher or oral tradition), the “thought” (philosophical contemplation), and the “known” (reflective or meditative understanding). | The expression “merely” (matta) suggests that these things are seen simply as they are, without being proliferated by conceit, or assumed to be absolute sources of truth.

sn35.95:10.2.pli: Yato kho te, mālukyaputta, diṭṭhasutamutaviññātabbesu dhammesu diṭṭhe diṭṭhamattaṃ bhavissati, sute sutamattaṃ bhavissati, mute mutamattaṃ bhavissati, viññāte viññātamattaṃ bhavissati;

sn35.95:10.3.comm: Whereas the six senses primarily stimulate an emotional response of desire, the epistemic tetrad is concerned with the creation of self-identity, responding to the Upaniṣadic idea that these are the means by which the Self is realized. | “By that” suggests that one assumes a Self from the tetrad, eg. by hearing about it, or deducing it from reasoning, etc. The instrumental case draws on Yājñavalkya: “By the seeing, hearing, thinking, and knowing of the Self, all this is known” (ātmano vā are darśanena śravaṇena matyā vijñānenedaṁ sarvaṁ viditam, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.5).

sn35.95:10.5.comm: Once the Self has been derived from the tetrad, one conceives Self in relation to it. Specifically, this rejects the imperishable Self posited by Yājñavalkya, which sees but cannot be seen. This again echoes Yājñavalkya, in a variant passage of the previous, although he is using the locative case in an absolute sense: “When the Self is seen, heard, thought, and known, all this is known.” (ātmani khalv are dṛṣṭe śrute mate vijñāta idaṁ sarvaṁ viditam, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.5.6).

sn35.95:10.7.pli: tato tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, nevidha, na huraṃ, na ubhayamantarena.
sn35.95:10.7.eng: you won’t be in this life or the next or in between the two.

sn35.95:10.8.eng: Just this is the end of suffering.”

sn35.95:11.1.pli: “Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi:
sn35.95:11.1.eng: “This is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement:

sn35.95:12.1.eng: ‘When you see a sight, mindfulness is lost

sn35.95:12.2.eng: as you focus on a pleasant feature.

sn35.95:12.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind full of desire,

sn35.95:13.6.eng: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

sn35.95:14.1.eng: When you hear a sound, mindfulness is lost

sn35.95:14.2.eng: as you focus on a pleasant feature.

sn35.95:14.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind full of desire,

sn35.95:15.6.eng: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

sn35.95:16.1.eng: When you smell an odor, mindfulness is lost

sn35.95:16.2.eng: as you focus on a pleasant feature.

sn35.95:16.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind full of desire,

sn35.95:17.6.eng: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

sn35.95:18.1.eng: When you enjoy a taste, mindfulness is lost

sn35.95:18.2.eng: as you focus on a pleasant feature.

sn35.95:18.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind full of desire,

sn35.95:19.6.eng: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

sn35.95:20.1.eng: When you sense a touch, mindfulness is lost

sn35.95:20.2.eng: as you focus on a pleasant feature.

sn35.95:20.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind full of desire,

sn35.95:21.6.eng: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

sn35.95:22.1.eng: When you know an idea, mindfulness is lost

sn35.95:22.2.eng: as you focus on a pleasant feature.

sn35.95:22.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind full of desire,

sn35.95:23.6.eng: you’re said to be far from extinguishment.

sn35.95:24.2.eng: when you see a sight with mindfulness.

sn35.95:24.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,

sn35.95:24.4.eng: you don’t keep clinging to it.

sn35.95:25.1.eng: Even as you see a sight

sn35.95:25.2.eng: and get familiar with how it feels,

sn35.95:25.3.eng: you wear away, you don’t heap up:

sn35.95:25.6.eng: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.

sn35.95:26.2.eng: when you hear a sound with mindfulness.

sn35.95:26.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,

sn35.95:26.4.eng: you don’t keep clinging to it.

sn35.95:27.1.eng: Even as you hear a sound

sn35.95:27.2.eng: and get familiar with how it feels,

sn35.95:27.3.eng: you wear away, you don’t heap up:

sn35.95:27.6.eng: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.

sn35.95:28.2.eng: when you smell an odor with mindfulness.

sn35.95:28.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,

sn35.95:28.4.eng: you don’t keep clinging to it.

sn35.95:29.1.eng: Even as you smell an odor

sn35.95:29.2.eng: and get familiar with how it feels,

sn35.95:29.3.eng: you wear away, you don’t heap up:

sn35.95:29.6.eng: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.

sn35.95:30.2.eng: when you enjoy a taste with mindfulness.

sn35.95:30.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,

sn35.95:30.4.eng: you don’t keep clinging to it.

sn35.95:31.1.eng: Even as you savor a taste

sn35.95:31.2.eng: and get familiar with how it feels,

sn35.95:31.3.eng: you wear away, you don’t heap up:

sn35.95:31.6.eng: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.

sn35.95:32.2.eng: when you sense a touch with mindfulness.

sn35.95:32.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,

sn35.95:32.4.eng: you don’t keep clinging to it.

sn35.95:33.1.eng: Even as you sense a touch

sn35.95:33.2.eng: and get familiar with how it feels,

sn35.95:33.3.eng: you wear away, you don’t heap up:

sn35.95:33.6.eng: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.

sn35.95:34.2.eng: when you know an idea with mindfulness.

sn35.95:34.3.eng: Experiencing it with a mind free of desire,

sn35.95:34.4.eng: you don’t keep clinging to it.

sn35.95:35.1.eng: Even as you know an idea

sn35.95:35.2.eng: and get familiar with how it feels,

sn35.95:35.3.eng: you wear away, you don’t heap up:

sn35.95:35.6.eng: you’re said to be in the presence of extinguishment.’

sn35.95:36.1.pli: Imassa khvāhaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmī”ti.
sn35.95:36.1.eng: That’s how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.”

sn35.95:36.3.pli: Sādhu kho tvaṃ, mālukyaputta, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāsi:
sn35.95:36.3.eng: It’s good that you understand the detailed meaning of what I’ve said in brief like this.” And he repeated the verses in full.

sn35.95:41.1.pli: Imassa kho, mālukyaputta, mayā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena attho daṭṭhabbo”ti.
sn35.95:41.1.eng: “This is how to understand the detailed meaning of what I said in brief.”

sn35.95:42.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
sn35.95:42.1.eng: And then Venerable Māluṅkyaputta approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

sn35.95:42.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mālukyaputto eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
sn35.95:42.2.eng: Then Māluṅkyaputta, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

sn35.95:42.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
sn35.95:42.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

sn35.95:42.4.pli: Aññataro ca panāyasmā mālukyaputto arahataṃ ahosīti.
sn35.95:42.4.eng: And Venerable Māluṅkyaputta became one of the perfected.

sn35.96:1.1.pli: “Parihānadhammañca vo, bhikkhave, desessāmi aparihānadhammañca cha ca abhibhāyatanāni.
sn35.96:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you who is liable to decline, who is not liable to decline, and the six fields of mastery.
sn35.96:1.1.comm: This topic is addressed in several discourses, including AN 6.62 and AN 10.55. A stream-enterer is not liable to decline (AN 6.97).

sn35.96:1.3.eng: And how is someone liable to decline?

sn35.96:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.96:1.4.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.96:1.5.pli: Tañce bhikkhu adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.96:1.5.eng: Suppose that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them. They should understand:

sn35.96:1.7.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’

sn35.96:2.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā uppajjanti …pe…
sn35.96:2.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears a sound … smells an odor … tastes a flavor … feels a touch …

sn35.96:2.2.pli: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.96:2.2.eng: knows an idea with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.96:2.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu adhivāseti nappajahati na vinodeti na byantīkaroti na anabhāvaṃ gameti, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.96:2.3.eng: If that mendicant tolerates them and doesn’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them, they should understand:

sn35.96:2.5.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls decline.’

sn35.96:2.6.eng: That’s how someone is liable to decline.

sn35.96:3.1.eng: And how is someone not liable to decline?

sn35.96:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.96:3.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.96:3.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.96:3.3.eng: Suppose that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them but gives them up, gets rid of them, eliminates them, and obliterates them. They should understand:

sn35.96:3.5.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’

sn35.96:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno jivhāya rasaṃ sāyitvā uppajjanti …pe…
sn35.96:4.1.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant hears a sound … smells an odor … tastes a flavor … feels a touch …

sn35.96:4.2.pli: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno manasā dhammaṃ viññāya uppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.96:4.2.eng: knows an idea with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.96:4.3.pli: Tañce bhikkhu nādhivāseti pajahati vinodeti byantīkaroti anabhāvaṃ gameti, veditabbametaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhunā:
sn35.96:4.3.eng: Suppose that mendicant doesn’t tolerate them but gives them up, gets rid of them, eliminates them, and obliterates them. They should understand:

sn35.96:4.5.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls non-decline.’

sn35.96:4.6.eng: That’s how someone is not liable to decline.

sn35.96:5.1.eng: And what are the six fields of mastery?

sn35.96:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno cakkhunā rūpaṃ disvā nuppajjanti pāpakā akusalā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.96:5.2.eng: When a mendicant sees a sight with the eye, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.96:5.5.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls a field of mastery.’ …

sn35.96:5.6.pli: puna caparaṃ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno manasā dhammaṃ viññāya nuppajjanti pāpakā akusalā dhammā sarasaṅkappā saṃyojaniyā.
sn35.96:5.6.eng: Furthermore, when a mendicant knows an idea with the mind, bad, unskillful phenomena don’t arise: memories and thoughts that tighten fetters.

sn35.96:5.9.eng: For this is what the Buddha calls a field of mastery.’

sn35.96:5.10.eng: These are the six fields of mastery.”

sn35.97:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you who lives negligently and who lives diligently.
sn35.97:1.1.comm: “Negligence” (pamāda) is from a root meaning to be mad or drunk. It’s often used in an ethical context, but here the Buddha extends it throughout the path.

sn35.97:1.3.eng: And how does someone live negligently?

sn35.97:1.4.pli: Cakkhundriyaṃ asaṃvutassa, bhikkhave, viharato cittaṃ byāsiñcati cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu.
sn35.97:1.4.eng: When you live with the eye faculty unrestrained, your mind becomes polluted when it comes to sights known by the eye.

sn35.97:1.5.eng: When the mind is polluted, there’s no joy.
sn35.97:1.5.comm: The discourse links “negligence” with the process of mental uplifting that leads to samādhi (see SN 12.23:3.11).

sn35.97:1.6.eng: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.

sn35.97:1.7.eng: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.

sn35.97:1.8.eng: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.

sn35.97:1.9.eng: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.

sn35.97:1.10.eng: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.
sn35.97:1.10.comm: “Principles” (dhammā) such as the four noble truths, dependent origination, etc.

sn35.97:1.11.eng: Because principles have not become clear, you’re reckoned to live negligently.

sn35.97:1.12.pli: jivhindriyaṃ asaṃvutassa, bhikkhave, viharato cittaṃ byāsiñcati jivhāviññeyyesu rasesu,
sn35.97:1.12.eng: When you live with the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.97:1.15.pli: manindriyaṃ asaṃvutassa, bhikkhave, viharato cittaṃ byāsiñcati manoviññeyyesu dhammesu,
sn35.97:1.15.eng: mind faculty unrestrained, your mind becomes polluted when it comes to ideas known by the mind.

sn35.97:1.16.eng: When the mind is polluted, there’s no joy.

sn35.97:1.17.eng: When there’s no joy, there’s no rapture.

sn35.97:1.18.eng: When there’s no rapture, there’s no tranquility.

sn35.97:1.19.eng: When there’s no tranquility, there’s suffering.

sn35.97:1.20.eng: When one is suffering, the mind does not become immersed in samādhi.

sn35.97:1.21.eng: When the mind is not immersed in samādhi, principles do not become clear.

sn35.97:1.22.eng: Because principles have not become clear, you’re reckoned to live negligently.

sn35.97:2.1.eng: And how does someone live diligently?

sn35.97:2.2.pli: Cakkhundriyaṃ saṃvutassa, bhikkhave, viharato cittaṃ na byāsiñcati cakkhuviññeyyesu rūpesu,
sn35.97:2.2.eng: When you live with the eye faculty restrained, your mind doesn’t become polluted when it comes to sights known by the eye.

sn35.97:2.3.eng: When the mind isn’t polluted, joy springs up.

sn35.97:2.5.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

sn35.97:2.6.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

sn35.97:2.7.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn35.97:2.8.eng: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.

sn35.97:2.9.eng: Because principles have become clear, you’re reckoned to live diligently.

sn35.97:2.10.pli: jivhindriyaṃ saṃvutassa, bhikkhave, viharato cittaṃ na byāsiñcati …pe…
sn35.97:2.10.eng: When you live with the ear … nose … tongue … body …

sn35.97:2.12.pli: Manindriyaṃ saṃvutassa, bhikkhave, viharato cittaṃ na byāsiñcati, manoviññeyyesu dhammesu,
sn35.97:2.12.eng: mind faculty restrained, your mind doesn’t become polluted when it comes to ideas known by the mind.

sn35.97:2.13.eng: When the mind isn’t polluted, joy springs up.

sn35.97:2.15.eng: When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil.

sn35.97:2.16.eng: When the body is tranquil, one feels bliss.

sn35.97:2.17.eng: And when blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.

sn35.97:2.18.eng: When the mind is immersed in samādhi, principles become clear.

sn35.97:2.19.eng: Because principles have become clear, you’re reckoned to live diligently.
